column1: Latest corporate unbundler M_reveals laid-back M_approach : Roland Franklin , who is M_leading a 697m pound break-up bid for DRG , talks M_to Frank Kane

M_On the other criticism he is equally dismissive .

The Franklin philosophy was learnt M_in the US leveraged buyout business M_at the M_side of Sir James Goldsmith .

M_In a takeover campaign that has already M_seen vitriolic language , he responds M_to the M_charge that he is M_mounting the bid to enrich himself and his friends by saying : ‘ Nobody could M_take M_that as a criticism — M_this is an investor group .

Obituary : Virgil Thomson
By PETER DICKINSON
VIRGIL THOMSON was a composer and writer of originality , courage and wit M_formed by a unique M_mixture of American and French influences .

M_In 1936 , three years M_before Aaron Copland , Thomson started writing film M_scores which were a M_model of unobtrusive M_clarity and pertinence , combining American M_materials to M_suit documentaries such as The Plow that M_Broke the Plains and The River M_with the musique d'ameublement M_approach of Satie .

Just as Thomson M_transferred Stein 's literary abstraction M_to music , so M_these M_portraits unusually M_employ the M_painter 's M_technique of M_drawing the M_sitter M_from life : an ideal combination of Thomson 's M_habit of M_immediate response M_with an actual M_subject .

M_This was n't it .
HOMICIDE
M_This chapter M_deals M_with the M_approach of the criminal law M_to behaviour which causes or M_risks causing death .

Murder , manslaughter , and several other offences are M_discussed , and one recurrent issue M_here is whether English law M_responds M_proportionately M_to the different M_degrees of culpability manifested M_in cases M_where death is caused .
7.1 DEATH AND FINALITY
For practical purposes , the M_culpable causing of another person 's death may fairly be M_regarded as the most M_serious offence M_in the criminal M_calendar .

There is an argument that treason is a more M_serious offence , since it M_strikes M_at the very M_foundations of the State and its social organizations , but treason is so M_rare that it is surely permissible to treat homicide as the most M_serious M_form of crime .
The reason for M_this is not difficult to M_find : the harm caused by many other crimes is remediable M_to a M_degree , whereas the harm caused by homicide is absolutely irremediable .

Even M_in crimes of violence which M_leave some permanent physical disfigurement or psychological effects , the victim M_retains his or her life and , therefore , the possibility of further pleasures and achievements , whereas death is final .

M_This finality M_makes it proper to M_regard death as the most M_serious harm that may be inflicted M_on another , and to M_regard a person who chooses to inflict M_that harm as the most culpable of offenders , M_in the absence of some excuse or justification .

Although many deaths M_arise M_from natural causes , and many others M_from illnesses and diseases , each year M_sees a M_large number of deaths caused by ‘ accidents ’ , and also a number caused by acts or omissions which M_amount M_to some M_form of homicide M_in English law .
For 1987 the statistics M_show that there were some 20,000 accidental deaths , of which some 7,000 occurred in the home , 6,000 M_at work , and 5,000 on the roads .
By comparison , the number of deaths recorded as criminal homicide was 600 , which M_includes all the murders and manslaughters .
M_This figure is relatively M_small when compared M_with many American cities , but M_that is no cause for satisfaction .
There are still awkward questions to be M_confronted .
For example , are we satisfied that the 600 deaths recorded as homicide are M_in fact more M_culpable than all , or even most , of the deaths recorded as accidents ?
M_In other words , does English criminal law M_pick M_out the most heinous M_forms of killing as murders and manslaughters , or are the M_boundaries M_frozen by tradition ?
Another question is whether the criminal law ought not to be M_wider M_in its M_application M_to activities which M_carry some risk of causing death than M_in other M_spheres .

Thus , even if it would be excessive to M_sweep M_large numbers of the deaths now recorded as ‘ accidents ’ M_into the law of homicide , there may be sufficient justification for M_creating or enforcing offences M_designed to ensure safe conditions of work , safe goods , safe buildings , and so on .
It was argued M_in Chapter 2 that the criminal law ought to M_spread its M_net M_wider M_where the potential harm is M_greater .

It will be M_seen that English law M_does M_this M_up M_to a M_point , and M_in the process seems to M_accept M_social-defence arguments as reasons for M_departing M_from several of the principles M_set M_out in Chapter 3 .

English law M_distinguishes M_between the offences of murder and manslaughter , as we shall see , but the two crimes do M_have certain common M_elements .
It must be proved that the defendant 's act or omission caused the death of the victim M_within a year and a day .
( The requirements of causation M_in the criminal law are M_discussed M_elsewhere . )

The ‘ year and a day ’ M_rule is a M_legacy of times when medical science was so rudimentary that , if there was a M_substantial lapse of time M_between injury and death , it was unsafe to M_pronounce M_on whether the defendant 's conduct or some other event caused the death .

Nowadays the problem is quite the M_reverse : medical science is generally M_able to M_determine whether D's conduct caused the death , and innovations such as M_life-support machines mean that life can be prolonged for months and years M_in some instances .
M_In one recent case the victim of a stabbing died two and a M_half years M_after the incident , having been M_kept M_on a M_life-support machine for almost the entire time .

M_In principle , it seems unjust that a homicide conviction should not be possible M_in such a case , if all the other M_elements can be established and only the ‘ year and a day ’ M_rule M_stands M_in the M_way .
But the M_rule was confirmed by the Criminal Law Revision Committee M_in 1980 , M_on the M_ground that a defendant should not be M_left M_in peril of a homicide conviction indefinitely .
Surely prosecutorial discretion should be enough to prevent unfair convictions years M_after the event .
The M_rule itself is M_out of accord M_with modern medical conditions and should be abolished .
M_DEFINING MURDER : THE INCLUSIONARY QUESTION
( a ) The Procedural M_Context

If causing death is to be M_regarded as the most M_serious harm that can be inflicted , it would seem to M_follow that the most blameworthy M_form of homicide should result M_in the M_highest sentences M_imposed by the courts .
Indeed , many M_systems of criminal law M_impose a mandatory sentence for murder ( or whatever the M_highest M_form of homicide is M_called M_in M_that M_system ) .
M_In some jurisdictions M_this is a mandatory sentence of death .
M_In others , such as M_those in the United Kingdom , it is the mandatory sentence of life imprisonment .
Why should M_this penalty be mandatory , and not M_at the discretion of the court as M_in other offences ?
One argument in favour of the mandatory sentence of life imprisonment is that it M_amounts M_to a symbolic indication of the unique heinousness of murder .
It M_places the offender M_under the State 's control , as it were , for the remainder of his or her life .

M_This is often M_linked M_with a supposed denunciatory effect — the idea that the mandatory life sentence M_denounces murder as emphatically as possible — and M_with a supposed general deterrent effect , M_in M_declaring that there is no mitigation of sentence available for M_this crime .
It might also be argued that the mandatory life sentence M_makes a M_substantial M_contribution to public safety .
None of M_these arguments is notably M_strong , let alone conclusive .

The mandatory penalty does indeed M_serve to M_mark M_out murder M_from other crimes , but whether the definition of murder is sufficiently M_refined to M_capture the worst killings , and only the worst killings , M_remains to be M_discussed M_below .

Whether the life sentence is M_regarded as a sufficient denunciation M_in society depends M_on the public 's M_perception of what life imprisonment means : if it is widely believed that it results M_in an average of nine years ' imprisonment , the effect will be somewhat M_blunted .

The same applies M_to the general deterrent argument : its effectiveness depends M_on whether the penalty for murder affects the M_calculations of potential killers at all , and , if it does , whether life imprisonment is M_seen as significantly more or less M_severe than the alternative of a M_long , M_fixed-term sentence .

As for public protection , M_this depends M_on executive decisions with regard to release ; it M_fails to M_take M_into M_account whether it is necessary for public protection to keep ‘ lifers ’ in for so M_long .
M_This M_brings the M_discussion M_to a crucial M_point : what does the sentence of life imprisonment mean M_in practice , and what would be the alternative ?
What it means is that the time of release from prison is determined by the M_Home Secretary , M_on the advice of the Parole Board and the Lord Chief Justice , rather than by the judge at the trial .

M_In procedural terms , therefore , the life sentence involves a M_transfer of function : normally it is the judge who determines the sentence ( or at least its M_upper M_limit , since earlier release M_on parole may be possible ) , whereas a life sentence M_entrusts M_that function M_to the executive , who must first ascertain the opinions of the Lord Chief Justice and the trial judge .
The Home Office is not M_bound by M_those opinions , and appears to M_depart M_from them frequently .

M_In 1983 the M_Home Secretary imposed restrictions M_on the release of persons M_serving life for murders of police- and prison-officers , terrorist killings , murder during robbery , and the M_sadistic or sexual murder of young children , M_fixing a minimum of twenty years ' imprisonment for M_these offenders .

Whatever the justifications for M_introducing M_this policy , it M_serves to M_underline the fact that sentencing M_in murder cases is M_enacted M_without each case being M_considered M_individually , M_after hearing representations M_from the offender 's counsel , and M_without a sentence announced in court and subject to appeal .
At present , the executive M_takes decisions to release some murderers M_after only a few years and to keep others in prison for extremely M_long periods .
Should M_those decisions not be M_taken by the courts , M_in the same M_way as other sentencing decisions ?
The answer sometimes M_given is that murderers should be treated differently because they are particularly dangerous : anyone who chooses to kill once can choose to kill again .

But M_this argument will seem less M_persuasive when we have M_discussed cases of manslaughter by reason of diminished responsibility : M_where a murder is M_reduced M_to manslaughter , the judge has a M_wide sentencing discretion and may , according to the facts of the case , select a determinate prison sentence , a hospital order , or life imprisonment .

M_In cases M_where life imprisonment was thought to be the appropriate sentence , the trial judge would still specify — in M_open court — the number of years to be M_spent in prison , M_taking the M_gravity of the offence M_into M_account , and release would be M_determined by a judicial tribunal .

( b ) M_Degrees of Homicide
English criminal law M_has two M_degrees of homicide , murder and manslaughter .
Many American jurisdictions M_have three M_degrees of murder — M_first-degree murder , requiring premeditation , and second- and M_third-degree murder , M_covering lesser M_shades of culpability .
In England there has been a proposal that we should do away M_with all M_these distinctions , M_leaving a single offence of criminal homicide .

M_That proposal , if implemented , would M_shift almost all the decision-making M_in homicide cases M_from the trial M_to the sentencing M_stage : the only issue of any consequence M_in most cases would be the sentence to be imposed , and all the distinctions now M_drawn M_at the M_stage of criminal liability would be M_reflected M_in the sentence alone .
The jury would M_have no M_role M_in most homicide cases , since a plea of guilty would be the norm .

Contrast M_this M_with the M_position M_in jurisdictions M_where there are three or more M_degrees of homicide : pleas of guilty M_to first- and M_second-degree murders would be less frequent , since there would be the possibility of argument in court ( if no M_bargain was M_struck beforehand M_between prosecution and defence ) , and the defence might M_succeed M_in persuading the jury to M_reduce the M_degree of the killing .
Moreover , the M_borderlines M_between the various M_degrees would M_raise questions of law , which would provide much opportunity for legal argument and for appeals .

M_That M_cost is not difficult to justify M_where M_capital punishment is the penalty for M_first-degree murder .

M_Where there is no capital punishment , however , the question of how many M_degrees of homicide it is desirable to M_have M_calls for M_careful M_weighing of the principle of fair M_labelling ( see Chapter 3.3 ( l ) ) M_against the M_cost and time arguments M_mobilised by the policy of efficient administration ( see Chapter 3.3 ( m ) ) .
The M_structure of the English law of homicide is rather strange .

Although there are two offences , murder and manslaughter , the latter M_includes two M_distinct varieties : ‘ voluntary ’ manslaughter ( killings which would be murder but for the existence of M_defined extenuating circumstances ) ; and ‘ involuntary ’ manslaughter ( killings for which there is no need to prove any awareness of the risk of death being caused , but for which there is thought to be sufficient fault to justify criminal liability ) .
The arguments therefore M_tend to M_focus M_on three borderline questions : What is the minimum fault required for conviction of murder ?
What conditions are needed to M_reduce murder to manslaughter ?
And what is the minimum fault required for a conviction of manslaughter .
( c ) Requirements for Murder
M_In English criminal law there are now two alternative fault requirements for murder : an intent to kill , or an intent to cause grievous bodily harm .
What do M_these requirements mean ?
Do they M_extend the definition of murder too M_far , or are they too M_narrow .

Probably the most accurate statement would be that a person intends to kill if it is his or her purpose to kill by the act or omission M_charged , or if he or she foresees that death is practically certain to M_follow M_from M_that act or omission .

M_In M_this M_way , both purpose and foresight of practical certainty are M_regarded as M_part of the definition of intent , although there are other statements M_suggesting that foresight of practical or ‘ virtual ’ certainty is merely evidence M_from which intent may be inferred .
How would M_this test be M_applied ?
In many cases the word ‘ intent ’ is used M_without elaboration , but there are some for which a M_full explanation of the meaning of intention is necessary .
A fairly typical M_set of facts is provided by Nedrick ( 1986 ) , M_where D M_had a grudge M_against a woman and had threatened to ‘ burn her out ’ .
One night he went to her house , poured paraffin through the letter-box and on to the front door , and M_set it alight .
One of the woman 's children died in the ensuing fire .
When asked why he did it , D replied : ‘ Just to wake her up and frighten her . ’

The question is : granted that D's purpose was to frighten , did he nonetheless realize that it was practically certain that his act would cause death or grievous bodily harm M_to someone ?
The jury should answer M_this by M_drawing inferences M_from the evidence M_in the case and M_from the M_surrounding circumstances .
What M_about the alternative M_element M_in the definition , an intent to cause grievous bodily harm ?
M_This M_has considerable practical importance , since M_this is all that the prosecution has to prove in order to obtain a verdict of guilty of murder .
It must be M_shown that the defendant intended ( which , again , M_includes both purpose and awareness of practical certainty ) to cause really serious injury M_to someone .
The House of Lords M_confirmed M_this M_rule M_in Cunningham ( 1981 ) : D struck his victim on the head a number of times with a chair , causing injuries M_from which the victim died a week later .
D M_maintained M_throughout that he had not intended to kill , but there was evidence M_from which the jury could infer — and did infer — that he intended to cause grievous bodily harm .

The House of Lords M_upheld D 's conviction for murder : an intent to cause really M_serious injury is sufficient for murder , M_without any proof that the defendant intended , or even M_contemplated , the possibility that death would result .
Does the ‘ grievous bodily harm ’ M_rule M_extend the definition of murder too M_far ?

If the M_point of distinguishing murder M_from manslaughter is to M_mark M_out the most heinous group of killings for the extra stigma of a murder conviction , it can be argued that the ‘ grievous bodily harm ’ M_rule M_draws the M_line too M_low .

By M_allowing an intent to cause grievous bodily harm to suffice for a murder conviction , the law is M_violating a general principle , M_turning the most M_serious of its offences M_into a M_constructive crime .
Why should it be necessary to ‘ M_construct ’ a murder conviction out of M_this lesser intent ?

There are arguments in favour of M_this : death is M_final , murder is the gravest crime , and there is no M_significant moral difference M_between someone who chooses to cause really serious injury and someone who M_sets M_out to kill .

No one can predict whether a serious injury will result M_in death — M_that may depend M_on the victim 's physique , M_on the speed of an ambulance , M_on the distance from the hospital , and M_on a M_range of other medical and individual matters .

If one person chooses to cause M_serious injury M_to another , it should be presumed that he or she realizes that there is always a risk of death , and such cases M_show a sufficiently M_wanton disregard for life as to warrant the M_label ‘ murder ’ if death results .

The counter-arguments , which would M_uphold the principle of correspondence , are that M_breach of M_that principle is unnecessary when the M_amplitude of the crime of manslaughter M_lies M_beneath murder , and also that the definition of grievous bodily harm M_includes a number of injuries which are most unlikely to M_put the victim 's life M_at risk .

M_In the M_leading case of Cunningham Lord Edmund-Davies ( dissenting ) M_gave the example of breaking someone 's arm : M_that is a really M_serious injury , but one which is unlikely to endanger the victim 's life .
So M_in practice the ‘ grievous bodily harm ’ M_rule M_goes M_further than the arguments of its M_protagonists would M_support .
Would it be right , then , to M_confine the fault M_element M_in murder M_to an intent to kill ?
M_That would M_have the merit of simplicity , but would it M_strike the right M_note socially ?

There are M_powerful arguments in favour of saying that there are other killings M_where an intent to kill can not be established , and yet M_where the moral or social culpability is equal M_to M_that M_in most intentional killings .

Of course , one can not be adamant M_about whether they merit the M_label ‘ murder ’ , because M_that is a question of M_drawing the M_line M_between murder and manslaughter , which is not susceptible of any precise resolution .

It is M_hard to argue conclusively that the category of murder should be M_smaller or M_larger ( unless the death penalty or a mandatory life sentence M_follows ) ; it is a question of social judgment .
Let us briefly M_consider some of the possibilities .
The fault M_element for many M_serious offences is intent or recklessness : why should M_this not suffice for murder ?
The question is whether all killings M_in which the defendant is aware of the risk of death are sufficiently M_serious to warrant the term ‘ murder ’ .

One answer sometimes M_given is that they are not , because a driver who overtakes on a bend , knowingly M_taking the risk that there is a car travelling M_in the M_opposite direction , should not be M_labelled a murderer if a collision and death happen to ensue .
M_This example M_assumes that a sympathy for motorists M_with M_overwhelm any tendency M_to logical analysis .
One might ask whether motorists are ever justified M_in knowingly M_taking risks M_with other people 's lives .

Yet if the example is M_modified a little , so that the overtaking is on a country road M_at night and the risk is known to be M_slight , it becomes questionable whether the causing of death M_in M_these circumstances should be M_labelled M_in the same M_way as intentional killings .
M_This is not to suggest that motorists should be treated differently .
The M_point is rather that , even though knowingly M_taking risks M_with other people 's lives is usually unjustifiable , M_taking a M_slight risk is less M_serious than intentionally causing death .
M_In M_discussing the M_boundaries of murder , we are concerned M_with classification , not exculpation .
To classify all reckless killings as murder might be too M_broad , but the M_point M_remains that some reckless killings may be thought no less heinous than intentional killings .
Can a satisfactory M_line be M_drawn M_here ?
One M_approach would be to M_draw the M_line by reference M_to the M_degree of probability .
Murder is committed M_in M_those M_situations M_where D caused death by an act or omission which he knew had death as the probable or highly probable result .
A version of M_this test of foresight of M_high probability is used in several other European countries ; it was M_introduced M_into English law by the decision M_in Hyam v.
DPP ( 1975 ) , but M_abandoned M_in Moloney ( 1985 ) M_on M_grounds of uncertainty .
A second M_approach is to M_frame the law M_in such a M_way as to M_make it M_clear that the court should M_make a moral judgment M_on the gravity of the defendant 's conduct .
M_Section 210.2 of the M_Model Penal Code M_includes M_within murder M_those reckless killings which manifest ‘ M_extreme indifference M_to the M_value of human life ’ .

Both the M_Model Penal Code test and the Scots test may be M_reduced M_to circularity , however , for when one asks how M_extreme or how M_wicked the recklessness should be , the only possible answer is : ‘ M_wicked or M_extreme enough to justify the stigma of a murder conviction ’ .

Admittedly , the M_Model Penal Code does M_contain a list of circumstances which may M_amount M_to M_extreme indifference , which M_assists the courts and M_increases the predictability of verdicts M_in a M_way that Scots law does not , but the M_essence of both M_approaches is that there is no precise M_way of describing M_those non-intentional killings which are as heinous as intentional killings .

Their M_protagonists argue that the law of murder is so important socially that derogation M_from the principle of maximum certainty should be allowed in favour of more accurate M_labelling by the courts ; M_opponents argue that the principle of maximum certainty is needed M_here specifically to M_reduce the risk of verdicts based M_on discriminatory or irrelevant factors , such as distaste for the defendant 's M_background , allegiance , or other activities .

A third , more precise M_formulation M_derives M_from the recommendations of the Criminal Law Revision Committee M_in 1980 , namely , that a killing should be classified as murder M_in M_those M_situations M_where there is an intention to cause M_serious injury coupled M_with awareness of the risk of death .

A fourth M_approach , M_adopted by English M_law M_until 1957 and still M_in M_force M_in many American jurisdictions , is some M_form of felony-murder rule : anyone who kills during the M_course of a felony ( or , more restrictively , a serious crime of violence ) or whilst resisting arrest should be convicted of murder .

Thus stated , there is no reference M_to the defendant 's intention or awareness of the risks : the fact that D has chosen to commit rape , robbery , or another M_serious offence , and has caused death thereby , is M_held to constitute sufficient moral M_grounds for M_placing the killing M_in the M_highest category .
Plainly , M_this is a M_form of M_constructive criminal liability : the murder conviction is M_constructed out of the M_ingredients of a lesser offence .

Presumably the justification is that D has already M_crossed a M_high moral/social M_threshold M_in choosing to commit such a M_serious offence , and should therefore be M_held liable for whatever consequences ensue , however unforeseeable they may be .

The objections would be M_reduced if awareness of the risk of death was also required : M_in other words , if the test were the commission of a M_serious offence of violence plus recklessness as to death .
The effect of M_that test would be to pick out M_those reckless killings which occurred when D had already manifested M_substantial moral and legal culpability , and to classify them as murder .
Four alternative M_approaches have been described , and many others could be listed .

The M_point is that the traditional concepts of intention and recklessness do not , of themselves , appear to be sufficiently well M_focused to M_mark M_out M_those killings which are the most heinous .
The law must M_resort M_to some kind of moral and social evaluation of conduct if it is to M_identify and M_separate M_out the most heinous killings .

Many people might think that a person who causes death whilst using an unlawfully held firearm or explosives ought to be convicted of murder because there is , generally speaking , no excuse for using such dangerous equipment .
Some of the people thus M_covered would be armed robbers , others would be terrorists .

The armed robber might say that he M_had no intention of using the firearm , that he carried it with him simply to frighten the victim , and that it went off accidentally : if the jury believes M_that , should he be convicted of murder ?

Many different M_lines of evidence may be used to flesh out the bare bones of the fossils .

Savannah animals differ M_from M_those of tropical rain forests , and M_these again M_from M_inhabitants of the tundra M_at M_high latitudes .
Looking M_at the fossil animal itself , the first necessity is to reconstruct it as accurately as possible M_from its fragmentary remains .

CONTROVERSY M_AMONG THE GIANT DINOSAURS

Action and Inaction in the Cities
Susanne MacGregor and Ben Pimlott

Paul Harrison 's Inside the Inner City : Life M_under the M_Cutting M_Edge M_focused M_on Hackney , a London borough M_ranked M_among the worst off M_on any M_scale of urban deprivation ( Harrison , 1983 ) .
Harrison describes ( p. 369 ) the M_way M_in which the inner urban powder-keg M_leads M_to a M_vicious M_circle , M_with many M_victims , but few individual M_villains :

The police force M_face the virtually impossible task of M_keeping the M_lid M_on the M_explosive M_mixture of M_ingredients that the M_dynamics of British society have M_assembled in the inner city .

The M_emphasis M_on ‘ crime ’ and the ‘ criminal M_acts ’ of the rioters M_in the official M_responses M_to the 1985 riots M_took a general and a specific M_form .

Potential M_Applications
Overview
Ian Masser

Given the M_extent M_to which geographic information management is M_applications driven , it is important to M_consider M_in some M_depth the characteristics of some potential M_application M_fields .

M_In the process it will be necessary to M_examine not only the M_extent M_to which geographic issues feature M_on the policy issues agenda M_in M_these M_fields but also the institutional M_context which M_governs decision-making and the M_extent M_to which data are available for research and policy analysis purposes .
M_Questions M_on data availability are likely to be particularly important where users are M_heavily dependent M_on secondary M_sources .
M_In M_situations of M_this kind M_provisions M_governing M_access and M_format may M_exert M_powerful constraints M_on the use that can be M_made of M_these data .
The first four chapters M_in M_this M_part M_examine issues relating M_to geographic information M_handling in terms of four potential M_applications M_fields .

The authors were asked to review the current M_state of the M_art M_in their M_fields M_with particular reference M_to the likely requirements of the future policy issues agenda in terms of the demands that they M_make M_on geographic information management .

Authors were also asked to evaluate critically the M_state of geographic information provision in terms of the needs of users and to M_consider the M_impact of user requirements M_on the development of geographic information M_handling methodology .
M_In M_this M_way the chapters M_in M_this M_part M_present a number of M_perspectives which essentially complement and M_amplify the M_discussion M_in the previous M_part .
M_In M_this case , however , methodological issues are M_tackled M_from a largely user standpoint , whereas M_in the previous M_part they were M_viewed as substantive problems M_in their own right .
M_In effect the M_product of the M_discussion M_in both M_parts is a M_matrix where the methodological issues are M_listed M_along one M_axis and particular M_applications M_fields M_on the M_other .
Figure 8.1 M_summarizes the main M_features of M_this matrix .

There are important differences M_between the chapters M_in M_this M_part both M_in the M_nature of the demands that they M_make M_on geographic information and also M_in the relative importance that is M_attached M_to geographic criteria as against other issues by planners and decision-makers M_in M_these M_fields .

The first three chapters M_dealing M_with environmental monitoring , natural and technological hazards and settlements and infrastructure M_applications M_make use of a very M_wide M_range of geographic information .
A major M_feature of M_these M_applications is the M_extent M_to which they involve M_overlays of a variety of information M_drawn M_from different M_sources M_on a topographic map M_base .
for M_this reason they M_make particularly M_heavy demands M_on current GIS technology both because of the M_size of the data sets and the diversity of the data M_structures that are involved .

Brown 's chapter M_on geodemographics M_discusses an M_application M_field M_where primary data M_collected for operational purposes are typically evaluated in relation to secondary data M_derived M_from M_sources such as the Census of Population .

It M_points M_to the M_impact that the findings of global environmental research are likely to M_have M_on most M_sectors of the UK economy .

M_This M_contribution also M_indicates the M_wide variety of groups that are involved M_in monitoring environmental M_change and M_draws attention M_to the M_role that the European Community is increasingly M_playing M_in M_co-ordinating M_these efforts .
